Gaius Marius: Overlooked as a battlefield commander?
Gaius Marius (157-86 BC) is often overlooked for his skills as a commander and remembered more for his contributions as a military reformer of the Roman Republic. This is extremely unfortunate as his battlefield experiences are what helped to formulate and shape his military reforms that in turn helped to drive his extensive military successes. [...] Mariusâ€™ first truly great military success after concluding the Jugurthine War in 106 BC was his massive success over the combined Teuton and Ambrone tribes at the battle of Aqua Sextia in Aix-en-Provence in 102 BC. Here Marius inflicted over 60,000 casualties on the tribes, took over 20,000 prisoners and captured the Teuton King Teutobod. He soon followed this up by engaging and then annihilating a massive Cimbri army at the battle of Vercellae, where 160,000 were killed and over 60,000 captured and thus ending the Cimbrian War (113-101 BC) and returning honor back to the Roman military (who had suffered their biggest losses since Cannae at the hands of the Cimbri and their allies). [...] These successes were made possible by the fact that Marius, who was not born of an aristocratic family and who was endlessly ambitious and driven to succeed, was above else, a soldier through and through.  From his early days in the army of Scipio Africanus to the midpoint of the Cimbrian War, Marius had a gift for assessing where the Republicâ€™s army was falling short and adapting it accordingly. The old Maniple Legion was too small, not mobile enough and not self-contained to be able to traverse, engage and then defeat the larger tribal armies that the Republic faced at the time. Gaius Marius (Latin: (/wiki/Help:IPA/Latin "Help:IPA/Latin"); c.â€‰157 BC â€“ 13 January 86 BC) was a Roman general and statesman. Victor of the Cimbric and Jugurthine wars, he held the office of consul an unprecedented seven times. Rising from a family of smallholders in a village called Ceraetae in the district of Arpinum, Marius acquired his initial military experience serving with Scipio Aemilianus at the Siege of Numantia in 134 BC. He won election as tribune of the plebs in 119 BC and passed a law limiting aristocratic interference in elections. # Gaius Marius

## Gaius Marius (157 - 86 BC)

Gaius Marius was born near Arpinum, and was the son of a small plebeian farmer. Contrary to popular belief, the Marius clan was influential locally, and maintained some limited client relationships with those in Rome.

Of equestrian but outside roots, Marius would find his early attempts to climb the Roman social and political ladder difficult at best. Using the legion as his route to fame, fortune and power, he would become among the most influential men of his day, and the history of Rome. [...] Marius was both a great general and a sometimes adequate, if not good, politician. He was credited with saving Rome by defeating the Germanics, and created an atmosphere of enfranchisement with the Italians that was a necessity for Roman growth.

The reform of the legions was of the greatest benefit to the army and Roman power, but perhaps above all else, he was a deep influence on the life of his nephew, Gaius Julius Caesar. [...] Ancient sources suggest that Marius was pre-destined, through the visions of a seer, to be Consul of Rome seven times. Not only would this prove true, but he would eventually be hailed as the third founder of Rome, and its savior.

Military glory and personal ambition drove Marius straight to the top of the Roman system, but perhaps even more importantly, the man and his legacy would have a profound impact on the life of his nephew, Gaius Julius Caesar.

As a youth, Marius may have used his modest family influence to join the Republican legions as a junior officer, or may have risen from the ranks. It is difficult to determine exactly, but it is known that he spent his early career in Hispania under Scipio Aemilianus, grandson of Scipio Africanus.
